subject: Art
title: Mood Boards
description: Assembling visual collections that define the feeling of a project.

hook.text: Before starting a creative project, professionals build a mood board: a curated collection of images, colors, textures, and typography that captures the FEELING of the project. It's a visual compass that keeps the work on track.

buildup.text: Mood board elements: color palette swatches, texture photos, typography examples, reference images (tone and mood, not direct copying), and sometimes words or phrases. Physical boards (pinned) or digital (Pinterest, Milanote, Figma).

discovery.text: A mood board answers the question 'what does this project FEEL like?' before you answer 'what does it LOOK like?' It aligns your emotional vision with visual decisions ‚Äî and helps communicate that vision to collaborators or clients.

twist.text: The power of exclusion: a mood board is defined as much by what it EXCLUDES as what it includes. If every collected image is warm, muted, and vintage ‚Äî that's a clear direction. One neon modern photo breaks the mood. Edit ruthlessly.

climax.text: Build a mood board for an imaginary project: 'a caf√© in a forest.' Collect 10-15 images that capture the feeling. Include colors, textures, lighting, and atmosphere. Notice how the board creates a unified vision before you draw a single line.

punchline.text: A mood board is a project's emotional DNA. Build it first and every creative decision becomes easier.

quiz.question: What is a mood board's primary purpose?
options: To capture the emotional feeling and visual direction of a project before detailed work begins
To collect as many images as possible
